subject: Developing reading speed
msgSnippet: I m a new member and have just stumbled onto QS recently when looking for information on Shavian. Looking through the boards it seems that a common problem is
messageBody:
I'm a new member and have just stumbled onto QS recently when looking
for information on Shavian.

Looking through the boards it seems that a common problem is that
people have a difficult time in reading the script as opposed to
writing it.

When I was in highschool, we had a "reading machine" which was a
device about the size of a toaster with a window on the front. A
short story (1-3 legal pages) was selected by the person doing the
testing (not the student) according to their reading ability.

The page(s) were fed into the bottom of the machine and scrolled
across the window at a preset speed. The student would do his/her
best to read the story and immediately take a vocabulary and
comprehension test based on the story read. If 8/10 of both the vocab
and comp. tests was achieved, the next session would be another story
of the same complexity but at an additional 10 wpm.

After 10 or so successful sessions (80%) the stories would advance in
both length and complexity. In this way I was once able to read at
1600 wpm and still achieve 80% comprehension.

I have not met anyone else who has had experience with the reading
machines but maybe it was more common that I once thought.

Perhaps someone on this list has some programming ability and could
slap something together along these lines?

Maybe this has already been discussed on the list and I just haven't
found it yet.

Rod.
